G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the matter in controversy exceeds $50,000 exclusive of interest and costs.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County under G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the Defendant operates the premises within Middlesex County, and the tortious conduct alleged herein occurred in Somerville, Massachusetts.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or occupier owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the leading Massachusetts case abolishing the common-law distinction between invitees and licensees and imposing a general duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. The quoted concurring passage criticizes treating trespassers differently, which presupposes that the majority has already extended a reasonable-care duty to all lawful entrants. Thus, the case supports the proposition that Massachusetts property owners/occupiers owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors, though it stops short of fully extending that duty to trespassers.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that “trespassers” stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant had a duty to maintain its premises in a condition reasonably safe for lawful visitors such as Plaintiff.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly frames the governing rule as the general premises-liability duty that a property owner owes to all lawful visitors. It states that a property owner must use reasonable care to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition, and then applies that rule to Target as the party controlling the parking lot. This directly supports the proposition that the defendant had a duty to maintain its premises in a condition reasonably safe for lawful visitors such as the plaintiff.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now abolish the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, and apply to all hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation of reasonable care that a property owner owes to lawful visitors regarding all other hazards… We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances….’”

Oliveri v. MBTA, 363 Mass. 165, 167 (197.proposition: Defendant had a duty to maintain its premises in a condition reasonably safe for lawful visitors such as Plaintiff.
Oliveri v. MBTA, 363 Mass. 165, 167 (197.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. MBTA, 363 Mass. 165, 167 (197.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the duty of one who controls business premises—to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or to warn of non-obvious dangers the owner knows or should know about. This is the standard premises-liability duty owed to lawful visitors such as the plaintiff subway patron, so the case directly supports the cited proposition.
Oliveri v. MBTA, 363 Mass. 165, 167 (197.relevant_excerpt: "1. The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know."

Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.raw_text: Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263 (1961)
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.proposition: The Defendant’s constructive knowledge is established by the existence of visible cart tracks and its employee’s admission that the spill had been observed before the incident.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.support_reasoning: The opinion does address constructive notice, but it rejects rather than accepts that the defendant had constructive knowledge on these facts. There is no mention of visible cart tracks or any employee admission of prior observation of the spill; instead, the court holds the evidence was insufficient to show the oil had been on the floor long enough or that employees should have discovered it. Thus, the case cannot be cited as authority that constructive knowledge is established by such evidence.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.relevant_excerpt: "There was no evidence, however, that the dangerous condition was caused by a person for whose conduct the defendant was responsible or that the defendant’s employees knew of the condition. In this state of the case it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence and taken steps to remove it or to warn the customers."

Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.raw_text: Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Mass. 273 (1911)
Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.proposition: The Defendant’s constructive knowledge is established by the existence of visible cart tracks and its employee’s admission that the spill had been observed before the incident.
Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.case_name: Anjou v. Boston Elevated Railway Co.
Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion finds constructive notice based on the old, dirty, and trampled condition of the banana peel and the duty and constant presence of an employee assigned to keep the platform clear. It does not mention any visible cart tracks or any employee admission that the spill had been seen earlier, so it cannot be cited for that specific proposition. The case supports constructive notice from the condition of the hazard and employee duties, not from cart tracks or admissions of prior observation.
Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The inference might have been drawn from the appearance and condition of the banana peel that it had been upon the platform a considerable period of time, in such position that it would have been seen and removed by the employees of the defendant if they had performed their duty. Therefore, there is something on which to base a conclusion that it was not dropped a moment before by a passenger… It was one of the duties of employees of the defendant, of whom there was one at this station all the time, to observe and remove whatever was upon the platform to interfere with the safety of travellers.”

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act with reasonable promptness constitutes negligence under well-established Massachusetts premise liability law.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The case does not frame negligence in terms of “failure to act with reasonable promptness,” nor does it articulate such a formulation as a well‑established Massachusetts premises liability rule. Instead, Sheehan adopts and explains the “mode of operation” approach, under which notice is satisfied by foreseeable risks inherent in the store’s self‑service operation, and liability turns on whether the owner took reasonable precautions commensurate with those risks. While the opinion discusses reasonable care and opportunity to remedy hazards, it does not establish the specific proposition that failure to act with reasonable promptness constitutes negligence under well‑established Massachusetts law.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “In sum, the adoption of the mode of operation approach will not modify the general rule governing premises liability requiring a plaintiff to prove that an owner had either actual or constructive notice of an unsafe condition on the premises. However, if a plaintiff proves that an unsafe condition on an owner’s premises exists that was reasonably foreseeable, resulting from an owner’s self-service business or mode of operation, and the plaintiff slips as a result of the unsafe condition, the plaintiff will satisfy the notice requirement… [T]he trier of fact [must] determine whether the owner… took all necessary reasonable precautions commensurate with the risks inherent in a self-service method of operation.”

Gallagher v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co..raw_text: Gallagher v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co., 332 Mass. 560 (1955)
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co..proposition: Defendant’s failure to act with reasonable promptness constitutes negligence under well-established Massachusetts premise liability law.
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly applies Massachusetts premises liability principles that a storeowner is not an insurer, but is negligent if, after having a reasonable opportunity to discover and remedy a dangerous condition, it fails to act. The court affirms that liability may be found where a foreign substance remained on the floor long enough, and in such a location and condition, that the defendant should have known of it and removed it with reasonable promptness; the jury could infer such a failure here, and the verdict for the plaintiff was upheld.
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co..relevant_excerpt: We said in White v. Mugar, 280 Mass. 73, at page 75, "The defendant owed to customers a duty to keep the premises reasonably safe for their use. He, however, is not an insurer of safety. Where, without action for which he is responsible, a dangerous condition arises, the law allows him reasonable opportunity to become informed of the danger and to take measures to remedy it. He is not liable, in such a case, unless he is negligent in failing to inform himself and to take appropriate action." ... The plaintiff’s right to recover therefore depends upon evidence from which the jury could find that the defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of and removed this foreign substance.

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: Massachusetts applies the standard of reasonable care toward all lawful visitors regardless of classification.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly reiterates that, under Massachusetts law, a landowner owes a common‑law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises, without distinguishing among invitees, licensees, or other lawful categories. That principle, originating in Mounsey and Davis, is treated as settled law and forms the starting point for the court’s analysis of the open‑and‑obvious danger and duty-to-remedy issues, thereby supporting the proposition that Massachusetts applies a reasonable care standard toward all lawful visitors regardless of classification.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. Id. at 743. This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973).”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.proposition: Proximate cause is established when the injury is a foreseeable consequence of the defendant’s breach of duty.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.support_reasoning: The court repeatedly links negligence liability to whether the harm was a reasonably foreseeable consequence of the defendant’s conduct. It states that a defendant owes a duty "to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct, with respect to all risks which make the conduct unreasonably dangerous" and emphasizes that reasonable foreseeability of the harm is the operative tort standard. The opinion then applies this foreseeability analysis to conclude that the shooting of the officer was a foreseeable result of the alleged negligent firearm storage, tying proximate cause to foreseeability in line with the proposition.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.relevant_excerpt: “Consequently, with some important exceptions, ‘a defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct, with respect to all risks which make the conduct unreasonably dangerous.’ … ‘To the extent that a legal standard does exist for determining the existence of a tort duty … it is a test of the “reasonable foreseeability” of the harm.’ … [T]he theft of the handgun by Jason, and its subsequent use in the killing of a police officer, was a foreseeable consequence of Kask’s not ensuring the proper storage of firearms kept on her property.”

Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..raw_text: Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass. 372 (1980)
Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..proposition: Proximate cause is established when the injury is a foreseeable consequence of the defendant’s breach of duty.
Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..support_reasoning: The court expressly ties causation to foreseeability, requiring that Edison’s negligence be a substantial factor in producing the injuries and that the harm follow from reasonably foreseeable impacts at non-excessive speeds. In rejecting Edison’s causation arguments, the opinion makes clear that an intervening negligent driver does not break the chain of causation where vehicle-pole collisions are foreseeable and the precise manner of the accident need not be anticipated. This aligns with the proposition that proximate cause exists when the injury is a foreseeable consequence of the defendant’s breach of duty.
Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Impact of a car with a pole could be expected to occur as a result of driver negligence and the design of the pole must take such mishaps into account.… He said also that to hold Edison liable the jury must conclude that Ramsdell was traveling, at impact, at a ‘reasonably foreseeable,’ i.e., nonexcessive speed. The precise manner of the accident need not have been foreseeable if impacts by moving vehicles were. Restatement (Second) of Torts § 435 (1965).”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Plaintiff seeks all appropriate damages under G.L. c. 231, § 85 and applicable common law principles.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: B. For prejudgment and post-judgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
